documents.title: early evening summary
text: david cameron has issued a heartfelt plea for scotland to vote to stay in the united kingdom .

speaking in aberdeen , he de the uk as a family , stressed the finality of the decision to break it up , insisted that scotland would get more powers without independence and admitted that he , and tory governments , would not be in power for ever .
on thursday , scotland votes , and the future of our country is at stake .
on friday , people could be living in a different country , with a different place in the world and a different future ahead of it .
this is a decision that could break up our family of nations , and rip scotland from the rest of the uk .
and we must be very clear .
there 's no going back from this .
no re-run .
this is a once-and-for-all decision .
if scotland votes yes , the uk will split , and we will go our separate ways forever .

gordon brown , the labour former prime minister and now the driving force behind efforts by the three main uk parties to commit themselves to greater devolution to scotland in the event of a no vote , has called for three guarantees '' for scotland to locked in '' before thursday .
they are : a guarantee that scotland will be involved in further constitutional change ; a guarantee of fairness ; and a guarantee the barnett formula will survive .
the white house has reaffirmed its opposition to scottish independence .
a crowd has gathered in trafalgar square where people are joining the let 's stay together event to express their hope that scotland votes to stay in the uk .
sunder katwala ( @ sundersays ) trafalgar square crowd for # letsstaytogether from vantage point of foot of nelson 's column that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: white house reaffirms its opposition to scottish independence
text: the white house has reaffirmed its belief that it would be better for scotland to stay in the uk .
at a news conference the press spokesman , josh earnest , just repeated what president obama said about this at a news conference in brussels earlier this year .
that does not really amount to a new intervention , although the spokesman could have sidestepped the question just by saying he had nothing new to add .
this is what earnest said when asked if president obama was worried about the break-up of the uk .
the president was asked about this when he attended the g7 meeting in brussels standing alongside david cameron .

what he said was that from the outside the us has a deep interest in ensuring that one of the closest allies that we 'll ever have remains strong , robust and united and an effective partner with the us .

this is a decision for the people of scotland to make , we certainly respect the right of the individual scots to make a decision along these lines , but as the president said , we have an interest [ pause ] in seeing the united kingdom remain strong , robust , united .
reporters then tried to get him to confirm that united '' meant the white house did not want scotland to leave .
earnest refused to do so , just saying the scots had a right to vote without outside interference .

but when asked if the white house was concerned about the uk becoming weaker in nato or at the un , earnest replied : i suspect someone in the administration has been thinking about that at some level , but i do n't know to what level it has been raised .

documents.title: cameron 's speech - my snap verdict
text: snap verdict : rarely have i heard a prime minister sound so powerless .

big prime ministerial speeches - the ones they deliver at party conferences , or on setpiece commons occasions , or when they have major policy to announce - are all about what the government will do , what levers of power it will tug , but this was n't like that at all .

it was more like a plea - polite , well-crafted , but with a slight edge of desperation - from someone who realises that , as an english tory three days after from the referendum , there is no longer anything he can do about a vote that could associate his premiership with the destruction of a 307-year-old union .

there was a tiny bit of prime ministerialism in it ; cameron delivered the most categorical promise yet that he would push through further devolution for scotland in the event of a no vote ( although he ignored the fact that some of his mps are opposed to this . )

he did not attack alex salmond personally and , although he warned about the dangers of independence - including claiming that scots may have to pack their passport when they 're going to see friends and loved ones '' ( in england ) under independence - generally it did not sound like a scaremongering speech .
cameron is often at his most passionate when talking about the family , and this was really a family speech writ large - a love letter to the family of nations that is the uk .
will it make any difference ?
the very fact that cameron 's visits to scotland have been few , and that he has avoided walkabouts , shows that he knows as well as anyone that his appeal here is limited .
still , it was heartfelt and sincere , and well-pitched .
if scotland votes no on thursday , he will look back on this ( rightly or wrong ) as one of the most important of his premiership .

documents.title: cameron 's peroration
text: cameron is winding up now .
as you stand in the stillness of the polling booth , i hope you will ask yourself this .
will my family and i truly be better off by going it alone ?
will we really be more safe and secure ?
do i really want to turn my back on the rest of britain , and why is it that so many people across the world are asking : why would scotland want to do that ?
why ?
and if you do n't know the answer to these questions - then vote no .
at the end of the day , all the arguments of this campaign can be reduced to a single fact .
we are better together .
so as you reach your final decision , please : do n't let anyone tell you that you ca n't be a proud scot and a proud brit .
do n't lose faith in what this country is - and what we can be .
do n't forget what a great united kingdom you are part of .
do n't turn your backs on what is the best family of nations in the world and the best hope for your family in this world .
so please , from all of us : vote to stick together vote to stay vote to save our united kingdom .

documents.title: cameron says tory government wo n't last forever
text: cameron is summing up his message to the scots .
tory government wo n't be permanent , he says .
we want you to stay .
head and heart and soul , we want you to stay .
please : do n't mix up the temporary and the permanent .
do n't think : i 'm frustrated with politics right now , so i 'll walk out the door and never come back .
if you do n't like me - i wo n't be here forever .
if you do n't like this government - it wo n't last forever .
but if you leave the uk - that will be forever .
yes , the different parts of the uk do n't always see eye-to-eye .
yes , we need change - and we will deliver it .

documents.title: cameron says no camp has the positive vision
text: cameron says the no side has the positive vision .
let no-one fool you that 'yes ' is a positive vision .
it 's about dividing people , closing doors , making foreigners of our friends and family .
this is n't an optimistic vision .
the optimistic vision is of our family of nations staying together there for each other in the hard times coming through to better times .
we 've just pulled through a great recession together .
we 're moving forward together .
the road has been long but it is finally leading upwards and that 's why i ask you to vote no to walking away .
in human relations it 's almost never a good thing to turn away from each other , put up walls , score new lines on the map .
why would we take one great britain and turn it into separate smaller nations ?
what is that an answer to ?
how will that help the ambitious young people who want to make their mark on the world or the pensioner who just wants security or the family relying on jobs make in the uk ?
cameron says the uk is a family .
we are a family .
the united kingdom is not one nation .
we are four nations in a single country .
that can be difficult .
but it is wonderful .

scotland , england , wales and northern ireland .different nations , with individual identities competing with each other even at times enraging each other while still being so much stronger together .
we are a family of nations .

why should the next generation of that family be forced to choose whether to identify only with edinburgh or only with london choose which embassy they want to go to when they are in trouble abroad or pack their passport when they 're going to see friends and loved ones .
a family is not a compromise , or a second best , it is a magical identity , that makes us more together than we can ever be apart so please - do not break this family apart .
so the vote on thursday is not about whether scotland is a nation .
scotland is a proud , strong , successful nation .
the vote on thursday is about two competing visions for scotland 's future .
the nationalists ' vision of narrowing down , going it alone , breaking all ties with the uk .
or the patriotic vision of a strong scottish nation allied to the rest of the united kingdom
cameron says scotland 's identity is already strong .

scotland 's identity is already strong strong scottish culture , strong scottish arts , a strong church of scotland and in the last 15 years you have built a strong scottish parliament not a fleeting institution but a permanent one .
cameron says a no vote will deliver change too .
'business as usual ' is not on the ballot paper .
the status quo is gone .
this campaign has swept it away .
there is no going back to the way things were .
a vote for no means real change .
and we have spelled that change out in practical terms , with a plan and a process .
if we get a no vote on thursday , that will trigger a major , unprecedented programme of devolution with additional powers for the scottish parliament .
major new powers over tax , spending and welfare services .

we have agreed a timetable for that stronger scottish parliament : a time-table to bring in the new powers that will go ahead if there is a no vote a white paper by november , put into draft legislation by january .
this is a timetable that is now agreed by all the main political parties and set in stone and i am prepared to work with all the main parties to deliver this during 2015 .
so a no vote actually means faster , fairer , safer and better change .
faster , safer , better '' - that 's the slogan unveiled by gordon brown on friday .

documents.title: cameron accepts the need for change
text: cameron accepts the need for change .
look .
the united kingdom is not a perfect country - no country is .
of course we must constantly change and improve people 's lives .
no-one is content while there are still children living in poverty .
no-one is content while there are people struggling , and young people not reaching their potential .
yes , every political party is different .
but we are all of us - conservatives , labour , lib dems , nationalists - on a constant mission to change our country for the better .

documents.title: cameron denies scaremongering
text: this is not scaremongering , cameron says .
these are the facts .
this is what would happen .
an end to the things we share together .
and the people of scotland must know these facts before they make this once-and-for-all decision .
to warn of the consequences is not to scare-monger it is like warning a friend about a decision they might take that will affect the rest of their lives - and the lives of their children .
i say all this because i do n't want the people of scotland to be sold a dream that disappears .

documents.title: cameron on the consequences of independence
text: it is his duty to spell out the consequences , cameron says .
it would mean we no longer share the same currency .
it would mean the armed forces we have built up together over centuries being split up forever .
it would mean our pension funds sliced up - at some cost .
it would mean the borders we have would become international and may no longer be so easily crossed .
it would mean the automatic support that you currently get from british embassies when you 're travelling around the world would come to an end .
it would mean over half of scottish mortgages suddenly , from one day to the next , being provided by banks in a foreign country .
it would mean that interest rates in scotland are no longer set by the bank of england - with the stability and security that promises .
it would mean - for any banks that remain in scotland - if they ever got in trouble it would be scottish taxpayers and scottish taxpayers alone that would bear the costs .
it would mean that we no longer pool resources across the whole of the uk to pay for institutions like the nhs or our welfare system .
this is not guesswork .
there are no question marks , no maybe this or maybe that .
cameron addresses those thinking of voting yes .
i understand why this might sound appealing .
it 's the promise of something different .

i also know that the people who are running the yes campaign are painting a of a scotland that is better in every way , and they can be good at painting that but when something looks too good to be true - that 's usually because it is .
and it is my duty to be clear about the likely consequences of a yes vote .
cameron turns to british values .
this is n't just any old country .
this is the united kingdom .
this is our country .
and you know what makes us truly great ?
it 's not our economic might or military prowess - it 's our values .
british values .
fairness .
freedom .
justice .
the values that say wherever you are , whoever you are , your life has dignity and worth .
the values that say we do n't walk on by when people are sick that we do n't ask for your credit card in the hospital that we do n't turn our backs when you get old and frail .
that we do n't turn a blind eye or a cold heart to people around the world who are desperate and crying out for help .
this is what britain means .
cameron says we built this country together .
the scots contributed .
it 's only become great britain because of the greatness of scotland .
because of the thinkers , writers , artists , leaders , soldiers , inventors who have made this country what it is .

it 's alexander fleming and david hume ; j.k. rowling and andy murray and all the millions of people who have played their part in this extraordinary success story the scots who led the charge on pensions and the nhs and on social justice .
that last line suggests he 's been reading gordon brown 's recent book on scotland .
cameron goes on about what would be lost .
no uk pensions , no uk passports , no uk pound .
the greatest example of democracy the world has ever known , of openness of people of different nationalities and faiths coming together as one , would be no more .

it would be the end of a country that launched the enlightenment , that abolished slavery that drove the industrial revolution , that defeated fascism the end of a country that people around the world respect and admire the end of a country that all of us call home .
cameron says he wants to speak to the scots about what is at stake .
i speak for millions of people across england , wales and northern ireland - and many in scotland , too who would be utterly heart-broken by the break-up of the united kingdom .

utterly heart-broken to wake up on friday morning to the end of the country we love to know that scots would no longer join with the english , welsh and northern irish in our army , navy and air force in our uk-wide celebrations and commemorations in uk sporting teams from the olym to the british lions .
the united kingdom would be no more .
david cameron is speaking now .
we meet in a week that could change the united kingdom forever .
indeed , it could end the united kingdom as we know it .
on thursday , scotland votes , and the future of our country is at stake .
on friday , people could be living in a different country , with a different place in the world and a different future ahead of it .
this is a decision that could break up our family of nations , and rip scotland from the rest of the uk .
and we must be very clear .
there 's no going back from this .
no re-run .
this is a once-and-for-all decision .

text: here 's faisal islam on the video they are showing before david cameron 's speech .

it looks as if the conservative mp nadine dorries did not get the memo about love-bombing the scots .

documents.title: david cameron 's speech in aberdeen
text: david cameron will be speaking in aberdeen shortly .

documents.title: darling urges yes campaigner to show more respect to opponents
text: alistair darling , leader of the better together campaign , has also renewed his call for members of the yes campaign to show more respect to their opponents .
he told sky news : this has got to be conducted in an atmosphere where people can speak out and express their points of view .
we do not want to live in the sort of country where people are afraid to do that .
we do not want to live in a country where people are scared to speak out , and we are not prepared to put up with it .
scotland will not be bullied into this , which is why a majority of people will say 'no thanks ' with pride .
alistair darling hackett/reuters

documents.title: even no vote 'could leave future of union , and trident , in doubt ' - report
text: chatham house , the foreign policy thinktank , has published a paper looking at the foreign policy implications of the referendum ( pdf ) , it is based on the conclusions of a seminar , involving parliamentarians and others , held under chatham house rules '' .
one of their conclusions is that , even if scotland votes no , the future of the union , and trident , would remain in doubt .
a no '' vote would not end the matter or represent a return to the status quo ante .
a no vote in which 45 per cent or more of the population in scotland vote for independence would still raise major questions about the long-term future of the union .
one participant pointed out that 45 per cent would be higher than the percentage of uk citizens who are likely to vote to leave the eu , according to data from the 2014 chatham house yougov survey .
the referendum has highlighted the strong and widely felt scottish opposition to the basing of trident in scotland .
questions around this arrangement would likely be revisited by the scottish government in the near future .
one participant suggested that , even in the event of a no vote , trident might still need to be moved from scotland .

documents.title: sir menzies campbell says federalism `` within touching distance ''
text: sir menzies campbell , the former lib dem leader and a scottish mp , says in an article in today 's scotsman that federalism , a longstanding liberal obsession , is now within touching distance '' .
here 's an extract .
who would have thought two years ago that politicians and civic groups across the united kingdom would have so vocally debated , let alone whisper , the need for a fully federal uk ?
whilst liberal democrats were first out the blocks with our plans for radical change , others have followed in quick succession .

ippr , stuc , former labour prime minister gordon brown , murdo fraser of the scottish conservatives , the financial times , prospect magazine , and others have given varying nods towards federalism as being the best future for scotland and the uk overall .
we can safely say that we have spurred our partners within our family of nations to look at reform with fresh eyes .
sir menzies campbell campaigning in edinburgh yesterday cardy/getty images
and here 's what danny alexander , the chief secretary to the treasury , is saying about the prospect of prices going up under independence .
it 's an extract from a speech he is giving in glasgow tonight .
then we heard from the retailers .
asda , b & q , and others .
they made the obvious point that in a smaller separate country , with higher costs , those costs get passed on to customers in scotland rather than being shared across the uk as they are now .
prices will go up .
jim sillars promised them a 'day of reckoning . '
pretty outrageous , though i doubt john lewis will be quaking in their boots at the thought of losing mr sillars custom .
so your shopping will be more expensive if we give up on the 'four for one ' offer of the uk .
pooling costs across the uk keeps prices down for every scot .
why should we run away from that ?
here 's the guardian video of alex salmond dismissing asda 's claims that prices could rise under independence .

documents.title: salmond rejects claim that the yes camp is involved in bullying opponents
text: alex salmond was asked about alistair carmichael urging him to stop yes supporters bullying their opponents .
( see 3.47pm . )

adopting the line that he has used before ( eg here , yesterday , and here , this morning ) he said there were a few idiots on either side '' but that generally the campaign had been perfectly civilised '' .
to suggest anything else is to demean the people of scotland , who are conducting this extraordinary democratic debate .

documents.title: alistair carmichael urges salmond to stop bullying by yes supporters
text: alistair carmichael , the lib dem scottish secretary , has renewed his claim that the yes side are engaged in bullying .
he told the bbc that alex salmond should stop it .

look at the reality of this : the people who are jostled in the streets , the people who are pushed off the streets are not alex salmond or nicola sturgeon or john swinney ; it 's people like john prescott and alistair darling .
and they 're pushed off the street by people waving yes posters .

if there is bullying here - and clearly there is - and now quite a serious atmosphere where people who are supporting a no vote do n't feel comfortable in saying so publicly ; and then at the weekend you get somebody like jim sillars coming out and telling them there will be a day of reckoning for any business that 's going to support a no vote ; you 've got a mob outside pacific quay , the bbc headquarters in glasgow , trying to influence their reporting of this referendum - these are serious , serious tactics to be adopted .
and really , the person who could stop it all , who could pull the heat out of this is alex salmond but time after time , despite every invitation to do so , he just ignores it .
carmichael made a similar claim in a speech on saturday .
earlier the snp sent out an endorsement from peter strachan , professor of energy policy at robert gordon university , who said independence could be good for energy prices .
but bloomberg new energy finance , an analysis company , has put out a paper arguing that investment in green energy in scotland would be under threat if scotland voted yes .
it 's main argument is that the length of time it would take negotiating green energy subsidies would deter investors .

this is from kieron stopforth , author of the research : during this period of negotiation , with oil , power and renewables support under discussion as well as the currency , defence and national debt , clean energy investors would feel less than confident about future prospects , and decisions will inevitably be delayed .

these delays could hit projects in the whole of the uk for a time , but the longer-lasting effect would be on those in scotland if they are unable to compete for support under the renewables obligation or contract-for-difference schemes .
and this is what the report says about contract-for-difference .

the contract-for-difference , or cfd , support scheme is currently being phased in , and in april the 664mw beatrice offshore wind project in scottish waters , costing an estimated $ 3.4bn , was selected by the uk department of energy and climate change ( decc ) for an early contract underpinning the price it will receive for its electricity .
decc is due to hold its first full cfd auction in october .
it has declined to say whether this might be delayed by a yes '' vote in the referendum .
alex salmond with keith anderson , ceo of scottish power renewables , during the official opening of mark hill windfarm in ayrshire , scotland in 2011 .
lawson/pa archive/press association images
my colleague frances perruadin has been talking to english students at edinburgh university to find out what they feel about thursday 's vote .
she says they are confused about what their status would be in the event of a yes vote .

charlotte stockton , 19 , a second year french and linguistics student from yorkshire , says that she will be voting no - she likes feeling at home in both scotland and yorkshire - and that she has no idea what her situation would be if the referendum returned a 'yes ' vote .
she will graduate in 2017 , so after 24 march 2016 , the date that independence would become official .

her friend nishith hegde , a 19-year-old economics student from birmingham , says he is annoyed about the uncertainty surrounding his fees : it 's not something i factored into my decision to come and study here . ''
he describes himself as a determined no voter . ''
i came as an immigrant to the uk and i know what it 's like to feel like an outsider in a place that 's supposed to be your home , '' he says .
i finally do feel at home in the uk and i do n't want to be dragged back to that position of feeling foreign . ''

freshers jacqueline easter , an 18-year-old medical student from london , and jessica raley , a 19-year-old classics student from lancashire , ca n't vote in the referendum as they have n't been living in scotland long enough to register and both are unclear about what independence would mean for them .
when i first applied to edinburgh i did n't think it was going to happen , '' says jacqueline .
but once you 're here it actually feels a lot more real , like it could happen . ''
nishith hedge and charlotte stockton perraudin
yes scotland has released an open letter signed by 18 armed forces veterans strongly objected to lord dannatt 's comments about independence yesterday .
dannatt , the former head of the army , suggested voted yes would dishonour the memory of soldiers who died in northern ireland defending the union .

the signatories include a 102-year-old former desert rat , jimmy sinclair , colin may , a former lieutenant commander and senior faslane naval intelligence officer , and keith brown , a former royal marine who is now the scottish government 's veterans minister .

they write : as former uk armed forces personnel , we take the strongest possible exception to the outrageous statement by lord richard dannatt implying that our fallen comrades died in support of a no vote in a scottish independence referendum .
how dare he take their sacrifice in vain and try to turn it to political advantage - particularly having presided over the destruction of scotland 's historic regiments .
people who serve in the armed forces and veterans hold a variety of different views on scotland 's future .
we are all voting yes on thursday , others will vote no .

it is that freedom to decide matters democratically which our service men and women have helped safeguard for generations - it is not about bolstering the position of a self-serving westminster establishment - and the people of scotland will choose on thursday .
we believe that choice should and will be yes .

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: economic issues have taken centre stage as the yes and no campaigns enter the final 72 hours before referendum day .
alex salmond , scotland 's first minister , has said that scottish business leaders are increasingly backing a yes vote .
more and more of scotland 's businesspeople and job-creators are backing a yes vote because they know it is the only way we will get the economic powers we need .
but labour has highlighted the threat to jobs from the potential loss of uk defence orders .

on a meeting with workers from bae systems in glasgow , john reid , the former scottish secretary and defence secretary , said : scottish shipbuilders are legendary and these workers are some of the best , and most skilled , in scotland .
meeting them again this morning just reminds us all that we 're voting no for better jobs , we 're voting no for more jobs , we 're voting no for a stronger scotland .
for these workers , and a million scots like them , the united kingdom really is a job creation machine .
the electoral commission has released its forth and final report on campaign donations .

as my colleague libby brooks reports , after better together comfortably reached its spending limit of £ 1.5m in the last round , there 's another £ 120,000 declared by yes scotland , coming from businessmen william tait and sir george mathewson .
elsewhere on the no side , the celebrity love-bombing campaign let 's stay together has received £ 10,000 from chelsea vice-president joe hemani .

in early june , the first report on campaign donations - covering the longest reporting period from december 2013 to june 2014 - revealed that the pro-union campaign had taken more than double the donations received by the campaign for scottish independence , with significant contributions from tory backers and senior financiers .
nicola sturgeon has suggested that yesterday 's anti-bbc protest by yes campaigners was a mistake , even though salmond has endorsed it .
( see 12.56pm and 12.24pm . )
speaking on the bbc 's daily politics , blair jenkins , chief executive of yes scotland , also defended the demonstration .
i think what we saw yesterday was an expression of anger , and expression of hurt that some people felt the bbc was n't doing its job as a public service broadcaster .
what people are reflecting is the sense that there was almost an unwillingness or an inability on behalf of london-based journalists to understand what 's happening here .
the local bbc scotland journalists tend to get elbowed aside by the other correspondents that arrive with the preconception that there 's something rather strange going on here .
salmond has suggesting that a comment from the queen reported as a pro-no intervention was misrepresented by the frenetic unionist press '' .
salmond has said that , after his visit to the north east of scotland today , the next time david cameron visits scotland it will be to negotiate independence .
this is said to be david cameron 's last campaign visit to scotland .

the next time he comes to scotland it will not be to love-bomb or engage in desperate last-minute scaremongering , and following a yes vote it will be to engage in serious post-referendum talks in the best interests of the people of scotland and the rest of the uk , as pledged in the edinburgh agreement .
danny alexander , the chief secretary to the treasury , has said that house prices could fall under independence .
he was quoting claims in a press release from the property website zoopla .
kenny anderson , managing director of anderson construction and anderson buchan property and former chairman of the chartered institute of building in scotland , said zoopla 's warnings were wrong .
zoopla is just looking for a headline as free advertising .
i buy and sell property all the time , i have n't seen any slowdown in the market and i have n't heard of anyone worrying about independence .

far from being a problem , the yes vote will open up opportunities in scotland and a supportive government will help address some of the problems that developers and house buyers in scotland are facing .

a ( self-selecting ) poll for pinknews suggests that 54 % of lesbian , gay , bisexual and transgender people in scotland will vote for independence 2,163 scottish readers took part in the poll conducted on the pinknews website on friday and saturday .
54 % said that they intended to vote yes , 44 % said that they would be voting no while 2 % said that they were still undecided .
among 1,204 non-scottish readers of pinknews , 87 % said that they opposed independence , 5 % supported it , while 8 % were unsure .
after the queen got involved in the referendum debate yesterday ( or did n't , if you believe alex salmond - see 12.24pm ) , what could top that ?
only god .
and now he is being called in .

the dean of durham , the very reverend michael sadgrove , is encouraging people to pray that scottish voters use their votes carefully with concern for the common good , '' ahead of the referendum on independence this week .
according to a news release , two prayers have been written , which have been placed at a specially created prayer station at the altar of st margaret of scotland , within durham cathedral .

sadgrove said : in these days leading up to the referendum , and on the day itself , we are inviting people to pray for the people of scotland and the whole united kingdom at this crucial time of decision .

we pray that all the people of scotland will use their vote responsibly and carefully with a view to the things that will enable our mutual flourishing so that these islands remain a secure home for all our people .
what we could easily overlook is that whichever way the vote goes , almost 50 percent of voters will be disappointed .
we need to pray for unity and reconciliation within scotland following the vote , and for the future of all the peoples of these islands , whichever way it goes .

although the church of england has not taken an official stance on this political vote , i believe that people in england should be given the opportunity to pray about something that will , in the end , affect us all .
in his news release sadgrove does not express a view on independence , but in a blog at the weekend he made it clear he was a firm unionist .

for scotland to say no to the union of which we have all been a part for 300 years would not only be a tragedy , but also a denial of a hard-won principle of human society that the united kingdom expresses , '' he wrote .
downing street have said that david cameron will spend the day of the referendum working in number 10 .
this has got to be the most ingenious endorsement of the day .
it 's alex salmond , citing adam smith to back the case for independence .
it 's a line he used when he met the press at edinburgh airport , but i missed it earlier .
this is the land of adam smith and it was adam smith who said no society can be truly happy if a great part of its people are poor and miserable .
scottish political economist and philosopher adam smith ( 1723 - 1790 ) archive/getty images

john reid , the labour former scottish secretary , told the bbc 's daily politics that it was not just voters in scotland who had the experience of getting a tory government when they did not vote for one .

there is no doubt that the frustration of voting labour and not getting a labour government is felt by many people , incidentally people in manchester , in liverpool , in newcastle , as well as in scotland .
that 's called democracy .
it 's also true that over the past 20 years for instance we 've had a majority labour government and next year we will have anbother labour government .
so sometimes you win , sometimes you lose .
john reid on the banks of the river clyde earlier today .
hackett/reuters

documents.title: sturgeon suggests anti-bbc protest was a mistake
text: nicola sturgeon , scotland 's deputy first minister , spent the morning campaigning with pensions .
my colleague libby brooks has sent me this .
nicola sturgeon has been meeting with pensioners at a cafe in hamilton this morning along with former scottish senior citizens unity party msp , john swinburne .
along with conservative voters , this is a demographic that the yes campaign has failed to make significant inroads with .
sturgeon insisted that she was seeing a shift of opinion amongst the older population : the polls and any on-street straw poll will tell you otherwise .

at this stage in the campaign , it 's hard to know how useful such events are in terms of changing minds : there 's the inevitable media scrum , the ordinary folk '' are carefully selected , and the politicians have neither time nor inclination to answer detailed questions .
sturgeon did talk about yesterday 's bbc protests in glasgow , emphasising that this was not a yes scotland protest .

she said : i 'm very clear in my view that we 've now got three days to the referendum and i would say to all to all yes supporters that we should spend every moment of those three days not protesting against something but campaigning for something , for a yes vote to give us the power to transform our country . ''
afterwards , i spoke to liz white and shirley watson , friends who drink coffee together most mornings and agree to disagree on the referendum .
that means we 've got what we journalists love - a split !
nicola sturgeon has suggested that yesterday 's anti-bbc demonstration staged by yes supporters was a mistake .
at this stage in the campaign they should focus on not protesting against something but campaigning for something '' , she said .
she spoke as alex salmond backed the protest , describing it as peaceful and joyous '' .
here 's libby 's audioboo of an interview with liz white and shirley watson .
scott ( @ scottscoot34 ) my own little independence baby blair with @ twitterid was a very proud moment .
thank you nicola # wearevotingyes ( this one 's not a pensioner , but it 's the only good twitter from this morning i could find . )
my colleague ben quinn has sent me more from the labour event on the clyde this morning .

veteran labour figures , trade unionists and workers launched a salvo again scotland 's first minister against the backdrop of the clyde - one of the labour movement 's historic heartlands - claiming that independence would put jobs in the multi-billion pound shipbuilding industry at risk .

the snp leader believed that sacrificing jobs in the sector was a price worth '' paying , claimed scottish labour leader johann lamont , who was joined by former labour minister john reid and trade unionists from sectors ranging from defence to the arts .

they also received a letter from 20 young shipbuilders , at the outset of their careers , challenging scotland 's first minister and intended as a rebuttal to a letter published in july by seven veterans of the 1971 upper clyde shipbuilders 'work-in ' who backed a yes vote this week .

paul sweeney , 25 , a bae worker and one of the signatories of the letter , said : as part of the uk , i know we will continue to have a bright future building ships for the royal navy at a state-of the-art new shipyard .
with independence , and the absence of any credible plan for shipbuilding , shipbuilding here wo n't survive . ''

others gathered on the clyde for the event included members of trade unions including unison and unite as well as members of the non-labour left , including some who recalled being contemporaries of john reid ( otherwise known as baron reid of cardowan ) when he was a young marxist at stirling university organising a protest against a visit by the queen .
and here 's ben 's audioboo of an interview with paul sweeney .

documents.title: salmond 's press conference - summary
text: it was n't a proper press conference , more of what we call a huddle '' , but it might just as well have been , because alex salmond answered quite a number of questions from reporters at edinburgh airport earlier .
here are the key points .
salmond endorsed the demonstration outside the bbc yesterday protesting about the corporation 's alleged bias and demanding the sacking of its political editor , nick robinson .

when a reporter suggested it amounted to intimidation and asked if salmond supported it , he replied : i think there is a real public concern , in terms of some of the nature and balance of the coverage .
you must allow people to express a view in a peaceful and joyous fashion .
that is part of the democratic aspect of politics .

my view of this referendum , if we leave to one side a handful of idiots on either side of the debate , which you 'll always get online or offline , my view of this is [ it 's been ] a joyous , empowering campaign , a lesson and a model and an exercise in true democracy .
he renewed his attack on downing street for trying to get business organisations to speak out against independence .
it was legitimate for business leaders to speak out as individuals , he said , but organisations should not be taking a corporate view without the approval of shareholders .
what troubled me is that the prime minister and the treasury are trying to get actual business organisation to state a company view .
that 's an extraordinary circumstance .
everybody in this country is entitled to express an opinion , whether they are a business person or an ordinary person .
that is what a referendum is all about .
but when you are trying to pressurise people and pressurise companies , as the prime minister has undoubtedly been doing , and indeed the treasury , that 's a different circumstances .
he also said 3,000 scottish business leaders had backed independence through business for scotland .
he renewed his call for an investigation into the way the treasury briefed journalists on the outcome of an rbs board meeting before it was over .
this was an emerging major scandal which is worthy of journalistic inquiry '' , he said .
he insisted that an inquiry must take place .
he said he did not support a boycott of supermarket firms like asda that have issued warnings about independence .
he insisted that the queen was absolutely impartial '' in the contest and he claimed that a comment from her yesterday suggesting otherwise had been misrepresented by the frenetic unionist press '' .
her majesty the queen is absolutely impartial in this referendum .

i thought the statement from buckingham palace last week made that totally clear nobody seriously , apart from some of the more frenetic unionist press , would seek to persuade or tell people otherwise .
he dismissed claims that independence would lead capital flight from scotland .
instead , he said capital was already leaving the uk because investors were worried interest rates were going to go up .
there has been tens of billions of pounds removed from the uk in the last few weeks .
absolutely nothing to do with the constitutional referendum here in scotland .
it 's about an expectation of an interest rate rise and therefore a fall in gilt prices .
that is what is moving markets .
i think markets will respond very postively to the prospective we have for an independent scotland .
jim waterson ( @ jimwaterson ) alex salmond pledges `` magnanimity '' and he will reach out to no voters on friday 's `` day of celebration '' .
# indyref
alex salmond has been talking to reporters at edinburgh airport .

in his comments , he endorsed the anti-bbc demonstration yesterday , renewed his attack on downing street for trying to get businesses to speak out against independence and insisted that the queen was impartial in the campaign .
i 'll post the quotes very soon .
severin carrell ( @ severincarrell ) .
@ alexsalmond gets mobbed by snappers at # edinburgh airport : what will it be like if he wins ?
# indyref
you can read all the guardian 's scottish independence referendum coverage here .
as for the rest of the papers , i 've already mentioned sir malcolm rifkind 's article in the telegraph and the david beckham letter .
here are some other articles worth reading .
scott macnab in the scotsman says alex salmond has already started talks with some european countries about an independent scotland joining the eu .
alex salmond has revealed that talks have taken place with major european states including france , spain and italy about the prospect of an independent scotland joining the eu .
the first minister also revealed that a number of members of his team scotland negotiating team have already been signed up and will move into action '' immediately after a yes vote .
scotland will need the support all 28 members states if it is to secure its eu membership as an independent country .

asked if he has already spoken to countries like spain , italy , france and belgium , who have all previously expressed concerns about their own separatist groups , mr salmond said : the answer is yes to all of these points . ''
andrew whitaker in the scotsman says a thinktank report claims that the loss of the financial sector after independence could cost scotland £ 9bn .
the loss of a large chunk of scotland 's financial institutions after a yes vote could cost the country more than £ 9 billion , a think tank has warned .

independence supporters have severely underestimated the economic risks of leaving the uk , with an overall black hole of £ 13 billion in scotland 's public finances , according to a report from the centre for policy studies ( cps ) .

a spokesman for scottish finance secretary john swinney last night rejected the report and said it was little surprise that a think tank co-founded by margaret thatcher is against an independent scotland '' .
jonathan brown in the independent say no campaigners claim that they were banned from holding a protest on arthur 's seat in edinburgh on the orders of the scottish government .

organisers had hoped that thousands of supporters in favour of remaining part of the uk would gather in the form of a human no on the site of the extinct volcano that overlooks the scottish parliament .
they were to symbolise what the no campaign claimed was the silent majority '' in favour of the status quo .

however , they were forced to move the location of the stunt after historic scotland , responsible for the site where 17 miniature coffins were discovered in the 19th century , said they could not climb the hill without its permission .
david torrance in the herald says the delegitimisation of the media in scotland is worrying .
no one could suggest the media is perfect , but its steady ( and quite deliberate ) delegitimisation over the past few years is n't healthy on any level .
witness the first minister at an international press conference on thursday , de the bbc 's political editor as little more than an adjunct to the treasury and fear factory known as better together .
yesterday yet another flying rammed home the message with a banner demonising a journalist for trying to do his job .
bias '' , meanwhile , has been redefined to mean writing anything a supporter of independence does n't agree with .
objective fact has become a matter of opinion while balance '' has replaced impartiality as the watchword of the state broadcaster mr salmond and his supporters so despise .
yet , paradoxically , that editorial approach has consistently favoured the yes side of the argument , not least when the polls were against them .

documents.title: danny alexander claims house prices could fall under independence
text: danny alexander , the chief secretary to the treasury , has been reading the zoopla press release too .
homeowners in scotland will be deeply worried by this news .
millions of scots have worked hard to own their home , and many more aspire to do so .
this is yet another example of how salmond 's reckless drive to a separate scotland would hit our pockets and household budgets .
over the last week we 've heard about the deep economic damage that separation would cause .
that is bound to have a long lasting effect on the construction industry , and on property values , and with higher mortgage rates making it all more expensive too .
the housing market has been doing better in scotland as part of the uk economic recovery , with over 2000 families being assisted by the help to buy scheme .
separation looks to more and more people like a 'help to lose ' scheme .
we still have time to avoid the risk to house prices set out by zoopla .
voting 'no thanks ' on thursday is the best way to protect your home , secure our economy , and secure the change scotland really needs within the uk .
alexander 's statement is in a better together news release headed : risk to house prices in the event of separation . ''

interestingly , the main better together release does not mention the claim that scottish house prices call fall by £ 31,000 on average. , although full zoopla press release , which does contain the figure , is included as an appendix .
that might be because alexander and his colleagues know that the £ 31,000 claim is so speculative that it barely rises above the level of nonsense .
if you do n't believe me , here is the extract from the zoopla press release setting out their reasoning .

property pricing is a function of demand and supply and with the recent announcements by a number of large businesses and employers in scotland of their intent to move south of the border following the referendum , a 'yes ' vote could increase supply of available properties while negatively impacting demand due to worker migration and result in a sharp fall in house prices .
further uncertainties following a 'yes ' vote surrounding tax , currency and interest rates are also likely to impact negatively on house prices in scotland .
mortgages could become harder to obtain with a more limited choice of lenders and higher interest rates could result .

and homeowners could be earning wages in a new currency but stuck with mortgages in sterling which would leave them exposed to currency fluctuations , struggling to pay their mortgage and in negative equity .
despite the gains of the past couple of years , scottish house prices still remain 2.2 % below their peak reached in august 2008 .
the data suggests there could be further to run in the scottish house price recovery , reflecting the wider economy which has been improving healthily in recent months .

however , if the economic impact on scotland is as severe as some recent market commentary has suggested , a 'yes ' vote could potentially create a market shock on a par with the recent financial crisis when house prices in scotland fell by 17.5 % , which would wipe over £ 31,000 off the value of the average scottish home and £ 85bn off the value of the total housing stock in scotland .
firms like zoopla , of course , put out press releases like this to get some publicity .
danny alexander jack/ ken jack/demotix/corbis
the daily express has got its splash sorted .
this is from the press assocation .
a yes vote could see a sharp fall in the average house price in scotland in the short-term , property pricing website zoopla has suggested .
the impact of a vote for independence could see the average property sell for £ 31,000 less than current prices , it said .
johann lamont , the scottish labour leader , and john reid , the labour former scottish secretary , are in glasgow meeting shipyard workers as part of a no campaign event .
my colleague ben quinn has sent me this .
ben quinn ( @ benquinn75 ) johann lamont , john reid and co with shipyard workers on the clyde .
an # indyref yes event ( slightly 'in the
the celebrity interventions just keep coming .
at the london fashion week the designer vivienne westwood told journalists she was a yesser .
it would be absolutely great if there is a 'yes ' vote .
the future could be just amazing and scotland would be very important and a influence on the world .
i 'm pretty sure she has n't got a vote , though .
she lives quite near me in lambeth , south london .
and the scottish actor brian cox has also been reaffirming his support for yes .
as the bbc reports , he told radio scotland 's morning call programme that labour had lost the plot '' in scotland .
i think the illegal act of the iraq war was a massive sin of hubris on tony blair 's part and i think it has traduced the party in the most incredible way .
when it comes to scotland , i am just ashamed of the way the party has behaved towards the people of scotland .
brian cox jack/ ken jack/demotix/corbis
and the snp has sent out an endorsement from an energy expert , peter strachan , professor of energy policy at robert gordon university .
strachan says independence could be good for energy prices .
i 've long thought that it is a complete disgrace that despite being one of the most energy rich countries in the world , far too many people in scotland are still affected by fuel poverty .
that is a damning indictment of the position scotland has found itself in within the united kingdom , and independence can help bring it to an end .
independence gives scotland key powers which can help bring bills down and it is also very clear to me that scottish energy will continue to be needed by our neighbours in the rest of the uk .
why ?
because it is a good value source of reliable energy supplies - and such sources are not plentiful .
better together have sent out an endorsement from sir dave brailsford , the british cycling performance director when the scot sir chris hoy when his olympic medals .

brailsford says : scotland has been a huge part of the success of british cycling , and i hope the uk stays together for the benefit of all sport , but especially olympic sports like ours i was born in england but raised in wales with welsh as my first language , and i feel passionately welsh , english and british , and i feel all the countries of the uk are a big part of my national identity .
kenny macaskill , the scottish justice minister , has accused david cameron and ed miliband of giving mixed messages to the scots .
this is what he told the bbc this morning .

i certainly think there 's something odd when the prime minister and indeed the leader of the opposition come up and say that they care and love us from heart and soul , and then in the next sentence say that pestilence and plague will befall our land if we have the audacity to vote for independence - that 's a clear mixed message .
i think our campaign is one of hope over fear .
this is our opportunity ; this is our chance to make sure we end a situation where we have a tory government that we 've never voted for .
and it 's happened not just once , it 's happened many times .
many people ca n't endure another tory government .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .

documents.title: john redwood calls for english parliament
text: john redwood , the conservative mp , wants more devolution for scotland ( promised by all main uk parties in the event of a no vote ) to be matched by the establishment of an english parliament .
this is what he told the today programme .
as a scottish parliament is going to have the power to fix income tax in scotland we need an english parliament to fix the level of income tax in england .
i want england to get the same devolution as scotland and i want england to get the government it votes for .
in 2010 we voted for a conservative government in england and scottish mps gave us a coalition .
you have to form the english parliament from the english mps .

i want them to meet as an english parliament and have our own english minsters on english issues just as the scottish parliament meets , but believing in economy i believe i can do both jobs with my colleagues as we do at the moment .
he explained how this would work .
mr redwood said some policy areas , such as foreign affairs , would still be under the remit of a union parliament .
[ foreign affairs is a ] union matter .
it would be decided by the union parliament .

we have a union parliament , meeting as it does today and then on other days of the week we english mps , within that union parliament , would form the english parliament and we would do all the devolved matters to balance the country .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .
john redwood

documents.title: labour accuse snp of lying over health
text: labour say they have caught scotland 's health minister , alex neil , red-handed contradicting himself on the threat posed to the scottish nhs by the proposed us/eu free trade deal ( the transatlantic trade and investment partnership - ttip ) .

in september last year , when asked about this in the scottish parliament , neil said : scottish government welcomes the transatlantic trade and investment partnership ( ttip ) talks and is maintaining close contact with the negotiations and ensuring that our views are fed into the uk government department for business , innovation and skills , which leads the uk input into the council in england the role of competition in the delivery of healthcare has increased with the private sector having a greater role in providing nhs-funded healthcare .
some commentators suggest that this may open up the nhs to further commercialisation under the ttip .
the position in scotland is quite different .
the scottish government has always protected , and will continue to protect , the nhs in scotland from privatisation .
the scottish government 's commitment to the people of scotland is for a publicly funded health service providing care free at the point of delivery .
but on the bbc 's westminster hour last night neil said the ttip was one of the biggest threats to the future of the health service in scotland '' .
in a statement margaret curran , the shadow scottish secretary , said : the snp 's lies on the nhs are falling apart .
the health secretary ca n't even agree with himself .
the truth is that the biggest threat to the future of the health service in scotland are the snp 's plans for independence .
they have lied throughout this campaign about the scottish nhs and they ca n't explain to people how the health service will be funded after independence .
margaret curran jack/ ken jack/demotix/corbis
and professor john curtice , the psephologist , was on the today programme earlier .
he said that , although the polls were narrowing , the no camp were still more likely to win .
it 's close , but one also probably concludes that still the odds on the no side winning are rather better than those on the yes side .
but , a few days to go , i do n't think anybody would be wanting to put too much money on the outcome .
he also pointed out that half of the scottish electorate did not vote in the scottish parliament elections in 2011 and that the vast majority '' of them would vote this time .

therefore , when the campaigns are thinking about how they are going to appeal to voters in the last few days , they need to bear in mind that probably the crucial audience does not consist of traditional labour voters , or people who have occasionally voted for the snp , but actually people who do n't have very much in the way of party loyalties .
curtice said that , for this group , the key issue was whether or not independence would make them better off .
as far as today 's paper 's go , there one scottish story that dominates : the queen 's decision to intervene ( sort of ) .
in scotland it 's the splash in the herald .

the scotsman leads on no referendum second chance warns salmond '' ( even though , if you listened carefully to what alex salmond said yesterday , it is clear that he does envisage circumstances in which scotland would not have to wait 20 years for another referendum ) and the daily record has got the yes campaign 's anti-bbc rally on its front page .

documents.title: rifkind says scotland , and rest of uk , would be less safe under independence
text: sir malcolm rifkind , the conservative former scottish secretary , defence secretary and foreign secretary and now chair of the intelligence and security committee , has made a bold claim in an article in the daily telegraph .
he says that not just scotland , but the rest of the uk too , would be less secure under independence .
here 's an extract .
the snp has made it clear that an independent scotland would have its own armed forces , intelligence agencies and foreign policy .
it has boasted that we could have one part of our island at war while the other part , scotland , remained neutral .
this should not be taken lightly .
it is what happened during the second world war , when ireland declared neutrality and closed its ports to the royal navy , even during the battle of the atlantic .
it is that serious .
as a former defence and foreign secretary , i have to say that the argument that a scottish army would provide the same security as we have now would be laughable if it was not so worrying .
on mr salmond 's own numbers , the proposed army would be 4,700 strong , which would mean combat forces of around 1,700 .
this would hardly make an aggressor tremble .
in addition , by removing trident from faslane , the uk could lose the ability to protect itself against a nuclear-armed state .

there is also disturbing immaturity in the nationalists ' assertion that the work of mi5 and gchq in preventing terrorist outrages in scotland , as elsewhere in britain , would be provided by a new scottish intelligence agency .
do they not realise that counter-terrorism can not be provided simply by building , a budget and newly recruited staff ?
it has taken mi5 and gchq more than 70 years to achieve their expertise .
scotland would become a much easier option for terrorists to commit outrages there or as a back route to england and wales .
sir malcolm rifkind
with three days to go , the scottish referendum campaign is getting a bit surreal .
i always thought that , if you were looking for a football figure likely to win the affection and respect of scottish fans , a former england captain was probably the last person you would choose .
but perhaps the german captain was unavailable , and so someone had the idea of getting david beckham to do his bit for the no campaign .
beckham has signed an open letter to the scots released by the let 's stay together '' campaign .
the achievement that gave me the most pride was to captain and play for my country , '' he writes , which is rather odd because that country was england , not the uk .

but he mentions being proud to represent the uk at the olympic bid and he says my sincere hope is that you will vote to renew our historic bond which has been such a success over the centuries and the envy of the entire world . ''
